case_name: Hazara Singh Gill v. State of Punjab

facts.text: Transfer Petition No. 9 of 1963 filed under S. 527 Criminal Procedure Code for transfer of cases Nos. 33/3 and 33/4 of 1963 under S. 52 of the Prisons Act pending in the Court of Magistrate Ist Class, Amritsar, to a competent Court outside the State of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Transfer Petition No. 9 of 1963. Petition under S. 527 Criminal Procedure Code for Transfer of cases Nos. 33/3 and 33/4 of 1963, under S. 52 of the Prisons Act, pending in the Court of Magistrate Ist Class, Amritsar, to a companypetent Court outside the State of Punjab.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 10, 1963 by HIDAYATULLAH J.

anchor.surface_text: May 10, 1963. The Judgment of the companyrt was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J.-This is a petition by one Hazara Singh Gill for the transfer of two criminal cases  Nos. 33/3 and 33/4 of 1963  under S. 52 of the Prisons Act, pending for trial in the companyrt of Mr. Sant Singh, Magistrate, First Class, Amritsar.

facts.text: Petitioner is Hazara Singh Gill.

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition by one Hazara Singh Gill for the transfer of two criminal cases  Nos. 33/3 and 33/4 of 1963  under S. 52 of the Prisons Act, pending for trial in the companyrt of Mr. Sant Singh, Magistrate, First Class, Amritsar.

facts.text: Petitioner is resident of village Rattoke in Amritsar District.

anchor.surface_text: The facts, in so far as they have been admitted by the State of Punjab, are as follows The petitioner is a resident of village Rattoke in the Amritsar District.

facts.text: Petitioner elected as member of Punjab Vidhan Sabha in last General Elections after defeating Hardip Singh, brother-in-law of Chief Minister.

anchor.surface_text: He was elected as member of the Punjab Vidhan Sabha in the last General Elections after defeating Hardip Singh, the brother-in-law of the Chief Minister of the State.

facts.text: S. Surrinder Singh Kairon, son of Chief Minister, and S. Ranjit Singh Grewal, Senior Superintendent of Police at Amritsar, married sisters.

anchor.surface_text: S. Surrinder Singh Kairon, son of the Chief Minister, and S. Ranjit Singh Grewal, who was posted as Senior Superintendent of Police at Amritsar, have married sisters.

facts.text: S. Mukund Singh, father-in-law of S. Surrinder Singh, owned vast lands, died without male issue, estate came under Court of Wards, petitioner obtained some lands.

anchor.surface_text: S. Mukund Singh, the father-in-law of S. Surrinder Singh, owned vast lands. S. Mukund Singh died without leaving any male issue and the estate came under the Court of Wards, and the petitioner obtained some of the lands from the Court of Wards.

facts.text: In May 1960, agitation for Punjabi Suba started, petitioner arrested under ss. 411/414 IPC, report sent under s. 107/151 CrPC, warrant issued.

anchor.surface_text: In May, 1960, the agitation for what is described as the Punjabi Suba was started and the petitioner was arrested under ss. 411/414, Indian Penal Code, and a report was sent against him under s. 107/151, Cr. P. C., and a warrant was also issued.

facts.text: Petitioner held for interrogation on remand by court.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was held for interrogation on a remand by the companyrt.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested in case under Arms Act.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was also arrested in a case under the Arms Act, and another, under the Indian Opium Act.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested in case under Indian Opium Act.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was also arrested in a case under the Arms Act, and another, under the Indian Opium Act.

facts.text: Petitioner's father and six others arrested on 26-1-1961 under s. 107/151 CrPC, discharged on compromise in court.

anchor.surface_text: His father and six others were arrested on 26-1-1961 under s. 107/151, Cr. P. C., but were discharged as a result of companypromise in companyrt.

facts.text: Petitioner convicted and sentenced to two years rigorous imprisonment in Arms Act case, sentence upheld by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was companyvicted and sentenced to two years rigorous imprisonment in the case under the Arms Act and that sentence has been upheld by the High Court.

facts.text: Petitioner convicted and sentenced to six months rigorous imprisonment in Prisons Act case, sentence confirmed by High Court, to run consecutively.

anchor.surface_text: He was also companyvicted in a case under the Prisons Act and sentenced to six months rigorous imprisonment, which sentence was also companyfirmed by the High Court. These sentences are to run companysecutively.

facts.text: Two cases Nos. 33/3 and 33/4 of 1963 pending, referred to Magistrate by Superintendent Jail Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: The two cases in which the transfer is asked for are number pending and they have been referred to the Magistrate by the Superintendent, Jail, Amritsar.

facts.text: Petition of S. Mohan Singh Tur transferred from Punjab to Saharanpur by this Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner points out that another petition of S. Mohan Singh Tur was transferred from the Punjab to Saharanpur by this Court.

facts.text: After election to Vidhan Sabha, petitioner unable to attend any meeting due to arrests and continuous jail.

anchor.surface_text: What is number admitted or evasively denied in the affidavit of the State Government are the following facts stated by the petitioner on affidavit After his election to the Vidhan Sabha, he has number been able to attend any meeting because he has been arrested and companytinuously kept in ail

facts.text: Petitioner is protagonist of Punjabi Suba, supported Akali candidates against Sadh Sangat Board supported by Chief Minister.

anchor.surface_text: that the petitioner is a protagonist of the Punjabi Suba, and supported the Akali candidates as against the Sadh Sangat Board which is supported by the Chief Minister

facts.text: In criminal cases, bail of rupees one lakh demanded from petitioner, father and six others.

anchor.surface_text: and that in the criminal cases in which the Peti- tioner was arrested, a bail of rupees one lakh was demanded from him as also from his father and six others.

facts.text: Father and others languished in jail for four months till discharged on compromise, petitioner continued in jail.

anchor.surface_text: Since such a heavy bail companyld number be furnished, his father and the other persons languished in jail for four months till they were discharged on companypromise in companyrt, while he companytinued in jail.

facts.text: Suit filed against petitioner by widow of S. Mukund Singh for Rs. 12,500 arrears of rent and eviction.

anchor.surface_text: Further, a suit has been filed against the petitioner by the widow of S. Mukund Singh for Rs. 12,500 for arrears of rent and for eviction

facts.text: In written statement of suit, petitioner alleged Court of Wards continued to save application of ceilings on land to property of Mukund Singh.

anchor.surface_text: , and in the written statement made by the petitioner in that suit, he has alleged that the Court of Wards is being specially companytinued to save the application of the ceilings on land to the property left by S. Mukund Singh.

facts.text: Petitioner claimed in suit that arrears of rent payable only by S. Surrinder Singh and S. Ranjit Singh Grewal.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has also claimed in that suit that if the arrears of rent have to be paid, they are payable only by S. Surrinder Singh and S. Ranjit Singh Grewal.

facts.text: This annoyed S. Surrinder Singh and S. Ranjit Singh Grewal.

anchor.surface_text: This has annoyed them.

facts.text: While petitioner in jail, S. Surrinder Singh with police force took possession of lands in September 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Further, while he was in jail, S. Surrinder Singh with police force took possession of the lands in September, 1960

facts.text: Criminal complaint filed against S. Surrinder Singh for threatening petitioner's wife with gun, dismissed for default of appearance as petitioner in jail.

anchor.surface_text: , and though a criminal companyplaint was filed against S. Surrinder Singh for threatening the petitioners wife with a gun, the companyplaint was dismissed by the companyrt for default of appearance of the petitioner as he was in jail and companyld number attend it.

facts.text: Superintendent Jail purposely referred cases to Magistrate instead of dealing himself for severe punishment to keep petitioner in jail away from lands.

anchor.surface_text: He alleged that the Superintendent, jail, has purposely referred these cases to the Magistrate instead of dealing with them himself, so that a severe punishment might be imposed upon the petitioner, and the intention is to keep him in jail, so that he may be kept away from his lands, his property and his other amenities.

facts.text: No specific denial by State, Chief Minister, or Superintendent of Police of petitioner's allegations.

anchor.surface_text: Further, the personal aspersions against the Chief Minister and the Senior Superintendent of Police, Amritsar, who have been charged with improper companyduct by taking advantage of their official position, should have been denied by them on affidavit, if they were untrue.

facts.text: Court reluctantly accepts petitioner's affidavit due to absence of specific denial.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any specific denial on the part of the State, the Chief Minister and the Superintendent of Police companycerned, we must reluctantly go by the affidavit filed by the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the petitioner has, by his affidavit, made out sufficient circumstances from which it can be inferred that he does entertain, and entertain reasonably, an apprehension that he would number get justice in these cases.

facts.text: Court transfers cases outside State of Punjab in interests of justice.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the present case is also one in which the interests of justice demand that the cases should be transferred outside the State of Punjab.

holdings.text: In proceedings of this kind, the Court acts upon uncontroverted affidavits without examining witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any specific denial on the part of the State, the Chief Minister and the Superintendent of Police concerned, we must reluctantly go by the affidavit filed by the petitioner. In proceedings of this kind, it should be known that the Court does not examine witnesses in support of allegations of fact made by either side. Ordinarily, the Court acts upon the affidavit of one side or that of the other.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transfer petitions proceed on affidavits alone; omission to reply leaves allegations uncontroverted.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any specific denial on the part of the State, the Chief Minister and the Superintendent of Police concerned, we must reluctantly go by the affidavit filed by the petitioner. In proceedings of this kind, it should be known that the Court does not examine witnesses in support of allegations of fact made by either side. Ordinarily, the Court acts upon the affidavit of one side or that of the other.

We are of opinion that the petitioner has, by his affidavit, made out sufficient circumstances from which it can be inferred that he does entertain, and entertain reasonably, an apprehension that he would number get justice in these cases. In similar circumstances, this Court has number hesitated on an earlier occasion to transfer certain cases outsid

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, an allegation of this type cannot be accepted, because it is impossible to think that there is no magistrate in the whole State who can rise above pressure, if any, brought by the Executive. However, the question is not one of finding such a magistrate and entrusting the cases to him.
